content:
If f:E→E′f : E \to E'f:E→E′ is a continuous map of étale spaces over some base topological space BBB, then it is an homeomorphism if and only if it is a fiberwise homeomorphism. (This is a translation of "a morphism of sheaves is an isomorphism if it is an isomorphism in each stalk".)

Are there any generalizations to this where the spaces EEE and E′E'E′ are no longer étale? For example, is it enough to assume that the structure maps π:E→B\pi : E \to Bπ:E→B and π:E′→B\pi : E' \to Bπ:E′→B are both open?

In any case, if f:E→E′f : E \to E'f:E→E′ is a fiberwise homeomorphism, then it is a bijection. So the difficulty is in showing that fff is open.

If EEE and E′E'E′ are both topological manifolds of the same dimension (not necessarily connected), then any continuous bijection f:E→E′f : E \to E'f:E→E′ is automatically a homeomorphism (by invariance of domains). So in this case, it is enough to check bijectivity, or equivalently, bijectivity in each fiber.

I was hoping for results that work for general topological spaces, but this already excludes some counterexamples.
If you already have some spatial counterexamples, that answers your question about open maps, since all spatial locales are open over the terminal locale :+1:

@Morgan Rogers (he/him) With "space" I meant "topological space", I'll edit what I wrote above. In any case, the implication "fiberwise homeomorphism implies homeomorphism" trivially holds over the singleton topological space.

I think I now have a counterexample thanks to the answers to a related question here:
https://math.stackexchange.com/q/3986209/

Let Q={(x,y)∈R2:x≥0, y≥0}−{(0,0)}Q = \{ (x,y) \in \mathbb{R}^2 : x \geq 0,~ y\geq 0\} - \{(0,0)\}Q={(x,y)∈R2:x≥0, y≥0}−{(0,0)} be the upper right quadrant with the origin removed.
Consider the action R×Q→Q\mathbb{R} \times Q \to QR×Q→Q given by λ⋅(x,y)=(2λx,2−λy)\lambda \cdot (x,y) = (2^\lambda x, 2^{-\lambda} y)λ⋅(x,y)=(2λx,2−λy).
Fold QQQ into a Möbius strip MMM by identifying (t,0)(t,0)(t,0) with (0,1/t)(0,1/t)(0,1/t).
The action of R\mathbb{R}R on QQQ descends to an R\mathbb{R}R-action on the Möbius strip MMM.
Now the quotient space is M/R≅[0,∞)M/\mathbb{R} \cong [0,\infty)M/R≅[0,∞).
The quotient map ρ:M→[0,∞)\rho : M \to [0,\infty)ρ:M→[0,∞) is open, and has a section sss given by s:[0,∞)→M, s(t)=(1,t)s : [0,\infty) \to M,~ s(t) = (1,t)s:[0,∞)→M, s(t)=(1,t).

Now consider the map f:R×[0,+∞)→Mf : \mathbb{R} \times [0,+\infty) \to Mf:R×[0,+∞)→M with f(λ,t)=λ⋅s(t)f(\lambda,t) = \lambda \cdot s(t)f(λ,t)=λ⋅s(t).
This map satisfies ρ∘f=π2\rho \circ f = \pi_2ρ∘f=π2​ and both ρ\rhoρ and π2\pi_2π2​ are open maps.
Restricted to a single fiber, fff is a bijection between two spaces that are both homeomorphic to R\mathbb{R}R, so by invariance of domains, fff is in each fiber an homeomorphism. However, fff itself can't be an homeomorphism, since the domain is contractible and the codomain isn't.

Together with @Joshua Wrigley I'm trying to find a nice characterization of "GGG-torsors" for GGG a topological group, and the above gives an example of what can go wrong.

Jens Hemelaer said:

Now the quotient space is M/R≅[0,∞)M/\mathbb{R} \cong [0,\infty)M/R≅[0,∞).

Can you explain how you arrived at this conclusion? I can't see where 000 comes from, for example.

Ah, I suppose the 000 comes from the identified axes, but since the R\mathbb{R}R action can move any point arbitrarily close to one of these, shouldn't that end up being a dense point in the quotient?

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

Ah, I suppose the 000 comes from the identified axes, but since the R\mathbb{R}R action can move any point arbitrarily close to one of these, shouldn't that end up being a dense point in the quotient?

Oh right... I should double check this.

Let f:M→M/Rf: M \to M/\mathbb{R}f:M→M/R be the quotient map. For quotients by group actions, the quotient map is always open. So the open subsets of M/RM/\mathbb{R}M/R are precisely the sets of the form f(U)f(U)f(U) for U⊆MU \subseteq MU⊆M open. Using this characterization, you can check that the topology on M/RM/\mathbb{R}M/R agrees with the topology on [0,+∞)[0,+\infty)[0,+∞).
I think that the fact we ignore the topology on R\mathbb{R}R when considering the action but not in the product was confusing me. :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:

Jens Hemelaer said:

Now consider the map f:R×[0,+∞)→Mf : \mathbb{R} \times [0,+\infty) \to Mf:R×[0,+∞)→M with f(λ,t)=λ⋅s(t)f(\lambda,t) = \lambda \cdot s(t)f(λ,t)=λ⋅s(t).
This map satisfies ρ∘f=π1\rho \circ f = \pi_1ρ∘f=π1​ and both ρ\rhoρ and π1\pi_1π1​ are open maps.

I still think something needs tweaking here, since when λ=−1\lambda = -1λ=−1, for example, you go outside the domain of definition of MMM. Maybe take (0,+∞)(0,+\infty)(0,+∞) instead of R\mathbb{R}R here?
The dot denotes the group action of R\mathbb{R}R on MMM, not multiplication. Not the best notation on my part, and I don't see a good alternative...
Okay, that's all of my confusions resolved now, I think, as long as by π1\pi_1π1​ you mean 2π12^{\pi_1}2π1​? :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

What I like the most about this example is that if you try something involving a more typical Möbius strip, such as the 1-dimensional vector bundle over the circle, you can't construct the maps you would need to construct a counterexample. The map [0,2π)→S1[0,2\pi) \to S^1[0,2π)→S1 isn't open, for example, so the mapping R×[0,2π)→M\mathbb{R} \times [0,2\pi) \to MR×[0,2π)→M can't be used as a counterexample.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

Okay, that's all of my confusions resolved now, I think, as long as by π1\pi_1π1​ you mean 2π12^{\pi_1}2π1​? :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

Hmm, π1\pi_1π1​ should have been π2\pi_2π2​ :grimacing: thanks, I edited it!

Jens Hemelaer said:

Together with Joshua Wrigley I'm trying to find a nice characterization of "GGG-torsors" for GGG a topological group, and the above gives an example of what can go wrong.

Interesting. Just to make sure I got things right: could you be a little bit more explicit about the connection between GGG-torsors and this example of a fibrewise homeomorphism that is not a homeomorphism? I understand that you've defined a map fff between two spaces R×[0,∞)\mathbb{R}\times [0,\infty)R×[0,∞) and MMM over [0,∞)[0,\infty)[0,∞), and I broadly understand (save for the details about M/R≅[0,∞)M/\mathbb{R}\cong [0,\infty)M/R≅[0,∞)) how your previous remarks show that fff is fibrewise homeomorphic. But what does this have to do with GGG-torsors exactly?

Is it that your example can also be interpreted as defining an R\mathbb{R}R-space, when we view it as ρ∘f\rho\circ fρ∘f defining an action R×[0,∞)→[0,∞)\mathbb{R}\times [0,\infty)\rightarrow [0,\infty)R×[0,∞)→[0,∞)? And that the failure of fff to be a homeomorphism relates to the failure of the desired induced map between R×[0,∞)→∼[0,∞)×[0,∞)\mathbb{R}\times[0,\infty)\xrightarrow{\sim} [0,\infty)\times [0,\infty)R×[0,∞)∼​[0,∞)×[0,∞) to be an isomorphism (which we require for an R\mathbb{R}R-torsor)? But is it obvious that M≅[0,∞)×[0,∞)M\cong [0,\infty)\times [0,\infty)M≅[0,∞)×[0,∞)?

@Ming Ng If EEE is a space with a GGG-action, together with a map p:E→Bp : E \to Bp:E→B such that p(g⋅e)=p(e)p(g \cdot e) = p(e)p(g⋅e)=p(e), then EEE is a GGG-torsor if and only if the map
ξ:G×E→E×BE, (g,x)↦(gx,x)\xi : G \times E \to E \times_B E,~ (g,x) \mapsto (gx,x)ξ:G×E→E×B​E, (g,x)↦(gx,x)
is a homeomorphism. It follows in particular that the action is free, and that the action is transitive on the fibers.
Further, there are natural projection maps π2:G×E→E\pi_2 : G \times E \to Eπ2​:G×E→E and π2′:E×BE→E\pi_2': E \times_B E \to Eπ2′​:E×B​E→E, and for these projection maps we have that π2′∘ξ=π2\pi_2' \circ \xi = \pi_2π2′​∘ξ=π2​. So ξ\xiξ is a map "over" EEE.

The question is now, is it enough that ξ\xiξ is a fiberwise homeomorphism to deduce that it must be a homeomorphism? This would simplify a lot, because on the fibers over some point x∈Ex \in Ex∈E, the map ξ\xiξ is given by the map
ξ:G→O(x), g↦g⋅x\xi : G \to \mathcal{O}(x),~ g \mapsto g \cdot xξ:G→O(x), g↦g⋅x,
where O(x)\mathcal{O}(x)O(x) denotes the orbit of xxx.

So in order for ξ\xiξ to be a fiberwise homeomorphism, it is enough that in EEE, each orbit is (in a natural way) homeomorphic to GGG!

Unfortunately, if a map is a fiberwise homeomorphism that doesn't necessarily mean it is a homeomorphism, see for example the map fff from above.

On the other hand, if EEE and E′E'E′ are both GGG-torsors over BBB, and g:E→E′g : E \to E'g:E→E′ is any GGG-equivariant map over BBB, then I think ggg is necessarily a homeomorphism (non-isomorphic torsors don't have maps between them). In the example above, f:R×[0,+∞)→Mf : \mathbb{R} \times [0,+\infty) \to Mf:R×[0,+∞)→M is an R\mathbb{R}R-equivariant map over [0,+∞)[0,+\infty)[0,+∞), which is not a homeomorphism. The domain is a (trivial) torsor over [0,+∞)[0,+\infty)[0,+∞), so this means that the codomain can't be a torsor (despite the orbits being all naturally homeomorphic to R\mathbb{R}R).
